metadata.h1: Data Science Roles: A Classification Problem
metadata.description: A look at the classification and trajectory of Data Science roles as perceived by practitioners and thought leaders. Career “future proofing” with recommended Data Science adjacent skills.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: One Data Science Job Doesn’t Fit All
Data Science for The Rest of Us
What Data Scientists Really Do, According to 35 Data Scientists

all_paragraphs: In surveying the Data Science landscape, it’s evident that this field is not a singular discipline. In an earlier post, I wrote that:
“…Data Science — which is also an art — is evolving at the intersection of technology, human curiosity and specific domain knowledge…”

Similarly the job title “Data Scientist” is not a singular role. It is essentially a catch-all term encompassing a wide body of knowledge and complex mix of skills and responsibilities. In his list of 30 Data Science Terms Explained, Alexander Eakins quotes DJ Patil, first Chief Data Scientist of the United States:
“A data scientist is that unique blend of skills that can both unlock the insights of data and tell a fantastic story via the data.”

This post will take a look at the ways some teams have attempted to classify various Data Science roles. It will focus on how job titles are organized at two large companies with mature Data Science programs, and will also introduce some essential non-technical skills from the perspective of one Data Scientist at a smaller organization. It will consider the trajectory of Data Science careers as perceived by industry practitioners and thought leaders. Finally, it will offer recommendations for some Data Science “adjacent” skills to obtain in order to add value and remain relevant in this rapidly evolving industry.

In her 2018 LinkedIn post One Data Science Job Doesn’t Fit All, Elena Grewal, Ph.D., Head of Data Science at Airbnb describes how rapid growth within the company (as well as lack of standard terminology within the industry) led to a tipping point:

“The downside of this variety within a given company is it can result in organizational confusion and churn, since partner teams don’t know what to expect from data scientists, and the data scientists themselves might be unclear on their role.”

To mitigate this issue the Airbnb team became strategic and intentional about creating roles which aligned business and talent needs, while also achieving clarity of expectations. The result was a restructuring of Data Science roles along three tracks:

While this level of Data Science specialization works well for a “hyper-growth” company like Airbnb, Grewal advises smaller companies to start with a more generalized approach.
Netflix relies on data to deliver personalized experiences for 130 million Netflix members worldwide. According to the Netflix Tech Blog:

Every day more than 1 trillion events are written into a streaming ingestion pipeline, which is processed and written to a 100PB cloud-native data warehouse. And every day, our users run more than 150,000 jobs against this data, spanning everything from reporting and analysis to machine learning and recommendation algorithms.
To support this gargantuan effort, Netflix employs data professionals in roles across three categories: Analyst, Engineer, and Scientist:
While job titles fit neatly into each category, there can be some overlap in tools and responsibilities between roles.

A larger company like Netflix may offer the “luxury” of many data professionals working in clearly delineated roles. At the same time, the sheer volume and complexity of the data will likely require each Data Scientist to have some generalized crossover knowledge in addition to specialized skills.

In his article Data Science for The Rest of Us, Oriol Mirosa, Chief Data Scientist at Shubh Loans offers his perspective on why Data Scientists at smaller companies should pay special attention to non-technical work. While acknowledging that technical skills are essential, he posits that particular soft skills can be a key indicator of success.
To Data Scientists at smaller companies where infrastructure and clearly defined data projects are not fully developed, Oriol offers the following advice:

The combination of critical thinking, curiosity, creativity and enterprise required to do these five simple things can’t be understated! This data-science-by-walking-around approach enables the Data Scientist to gain domain knowledge, understand business data and problems, and to conceive better business metrics and data products. The credibility gained from working closely with stakeholders will also make it easier to request the resources required to build out infrastructure, data and models down the road.
In his post on AI trends of 2018, Emmanuel Ameisen expresses that:

“When it comes to recruiting, Hiring Managers of teams all over the valley most often complain that while there is no shortage of people able to train models on a dataset, they need engineers that can build data driven products.”

While Data Scientists will perform the data wrangling and statistical analysis required to build Machine Learning models, they may not always have the skills required to integrate their prototyped models into a production environment. Increasingly, this is where the expertise of Machine Learning Engineers is being leveraged.
Tomasz Dudek, a Machine Learning Engineer explains that:

“. . . somebody has to glue all the “data science” and “software” parts together. Take the trained model and make it work on quality production environment. Schedule batch jobs recalculating insight tables. Serve model in real time and monitor its performance in the wild. And this is the exact area in which machine learning engineer shines.”

In her article Data science is different now, practitioner and thought leader Vicki Boykis reminds us that:

“While tuning models, visualization, and analysis make up some component of your time as a data scientist, data science is and has always been primarily about getting clean data in a single place to be used for interpolation.”

I hope this post has provided a framework for classifying Data Science roles, as well as some insight into the evolving scope of Data Science work. Elena Grewal, Ph.D., Head of Data Science at Airbnb offers this food for thought on shaping the conversation around development of standard classification terminology:
“In data science, the more we can join forces to establish norms, the more rapidly our industry will mature and the more equipped we as individuals will be to navigate it.”
For some additional perspective, check out this 2018 Harvard Business Review compilation of interviews by Hugo Bowne-Anderson on What Data Scientists Really Do, According to 35 Data Scientists.
